reflection:
1. After 1-frame NOOP nothing changed—Mario stayed at (2,4) with two pipes still directly ahead.  
2. The idle frame was ineffective; it neither advanced Mario nor prepared a jump over the first small pipe.  
3. Current pattern: brief pauses after movement waste frames and risk losing running speed needed for pipe clearance.  
4. Hold Right + Run and initiate a timely jump as the front edge of the small pipe approaches; maintain momentum to land past both pipes and avoid further stalls.

Mario’s run-and-jump burst cleared the pair of pipes: they’re gone from the viewport and no threats remain. The move was appropriate—momentum plus height avoided collision and kept pace with the scroll. Watch for the tendency to jump blindly; it works now, but unseen enemies or gaps could punish it. With bricks and two question blocks overhead, pause for a controlled hop to grab potential power-ups, then resume a rightward, low-arc sprint.

1. After the last [right,B], Mario’s position is unchanged (x = 0, y = 1). The three ground-level brick blocks disappeared, but no coins, power-ups, or threats emerged.  
2. The action achieved no forward movement or item gain, so it was ineffective.  
3. Repeated “run” inputs while Mario is stalled waste frames; something is blocking or the d-pad isn’t registered until jumping or repositioning.  
4. Add a jump (A) to clear the obstacle and reach the question blocks at (3,2)/(4,2). Breaking or activating them could yield power-ups that make advancing safer.

1. Mario advanced one tile right and gained one tile of height, landing on the brick-block row; no enemies or gaps appeared.  
2. Continuous [right,B] kept momentum and safely elevated Mario, so it was effective though progress was modest.  
3. With no threats, the main risk is stalling—short hops cost time and may miss block hits; coordinates show question blocks now one tile above Mario’s head.  
4. Keep holding B and right, add a full jump (A) soon to strike the question blocks or clear them, while scanning for incoming enemies as the screen scrolls.

Mario moved up one tile (y 2→3) but didn’t advance horizontally (x 1→1); a Goomba has entered medium range ahead. Holding only right failed to clear the brick line, so progress stalled and the enemy is closing. Repeated horizontal pushes against obstacles waste time and invite danger. Remember: when bricks or blocks sit at ground level, mix in jumps—right + A (with B for speed)—to vault them, tap the question blocks for a possible power-up, and gain height to safely stomp or bypass the Goomba.

1. Despite a 15-frame run-and-jump command, Mario’s x stayed at 1 and y dropped to 4; he slipped off the block instead of advancing.  
2. The move failed—Mario gained no ground and the Goomba is now flagged as an immediate threat.  
3. Repeated “right,A,B” is being cancelled by a front-edge collision; we’re stuck at the screen’s left while enemies approach.  
4. Next: clear the lip at x2 by holding RIGHT longer before jumping, then leap onto/over the question blocks or stomp the Goomba. Seek a power-up from the blocks to secure safety.

After the 20-frame run-jump, Mario advanced one tile and gained height, grabbing a power-up and turning big. The prior goomba threat was cleared; no damage taken. Overall, the continuous [right+A+B] was effective: it avoided danger, secured an upgrade, and kept momentum. Pattern: we’re defaulting to long bursts of the same input—good for open stretches but risky if an unexpected obstacle appears. Upcoming medium-range koopa now replaces the goomba, so prepare to release B to brake or time a stomp/shell kick. Continue using jumps to hit question blocks but stay ready to adjust inputs quickly.

Mario jumped up one tile but barely advanced; the Koopa scrolled off-screen, a Goomba is now close, and Mario shrank to small—showing he was hit. The brief right-run without a jump failed to dodge or stomp the threat, so the move back-fired. Repeated forward bursts without vertical evasion leave Mario exposed to ground enemies. Next, hop or stomp the Goomba immediately, or hit the nearby question blocks for a potential power-up before pushing right. Keep momentum balanced with timely jumps to stay big and safer.

• Mario dropped one tile but stayed at x = 2; the goomba is now “very close,” so danger increased, not decreased.  
• Run-jump was ineffective: the low question block halted forward momentum and the jump didn’t clear or stomp the goomba.  
• Recurring issue: jumping too late/too low under low ceilings keeps Mario stationary while enemies advance.  
• Next time, create horizontal space first—either backstep, then full jump onto/over the block row, or time a quick forward hop to stomp the goomba before it reaches Mario.

Jump-running right let Mario vault the Goomba, crack a question block, grab the mushroom, and land one tile higher. He’s now Big and the Goomba is gone—an ideal response. The “forward jump while running” pattern reliably handles ground foes and hits blocks, but it can spawn new threats off-screen. Immediate concerns: a close Koopa and a small pipe ahead. Stay on the upper blocks or time a downward stomp/kick on the Koopa, then prepare to hop the pipe cleanly.
